text: A single man, raking hay: Franz Jagerstatter, 36 years ol In the distance the steeple of a church and the village w he lives. A few dozen houses, the mountains rising up bey them. * St. Radegund is a small, peaceful village of 500 souls. A its center stands a small square; on one side a Gasthaus, inn; on the other, the rectory. A river flows nearby. The Salzach. Cows graze in the sun. clank of their bells, the lazy swish of their tails. * Returning home from the fields, Franz exchanges greetings with his neighbors. A burn-in reads: “Austria, 1940.”

He joins his wife, Franziska, 30. Their daughters, 2 and years old, run out of the barn which stands next to the house. A calf, just born, wobbles to its feet. Franz call Franziska by her nickname, Fani. *
Girls, help your father! The girl’s names are Rosi and Maridl. Franz picks Maridl and puts her on his shoulders, while Rosi begs to be take the same way. A bell rings in the distance.

Franz dances on the terrace of the inn. Fani laughs and claps. Together they gather plums and apples from the trees in t small orchard. Fani yokes up a cow and sets her to plow. Armed with stones, the children drive crows off the fresh sown fields. Fani milks the cows, makes soap, churns butter. she negotiates with the local miller to have their wheat grou into flour. Rosalia, Franz’s mother, lives with the family and joins out in the fields. She is a widow. Franz’s father died in First World War.
Mother, stay out of the sun. Husband and wife help their neighbors and are helped in t haying, whitewashing their houses, digging out a well. Th rely on each other, a close-knit community.

Beyond his work as a farmer, Franz serves as a sacristan the church. He trims the candles, polishes the pews, ring the bell. He refuses to accept any payment the parishione offer him for his role in arranging baptisms, weddings an funerals. He watches as a painter refurbishes the ceiling with cher and seraphim in transports of ecstasy. He pinches the dead blooms off the roses that grow over t graves of the churchyard outside.
Franz helps his mother up a flight of stairs. She is a brooding woman, worn by trouble and care.
War scenes from the Eastern Front. German and Russian for plod through the snow, exhausted. Tanks advance by night. Howitzers light up the sky. Stalingrad. Kursk.
Franz and Fani put the children to bed. The girls cry out with delight as their father makes shadows on the ceiling Soon they are asleep, and the house is still.

These last weeks you're different. What is it? Talk with me. She remembers him in a happy time, riding through the Alp his motorcycle, at a time when he still owned one. His sm as she looked at him. There has been no threat to their happiness. Only a momen few weeks ago, when she heard a faint roar and, looking u barely made out the silhouettes of British planes, bomber in the sky high above, far away. How could the war touch their kingdom, or disturb their peace, when they are so insignificant in the scheme of things, so far from Vienna and Berlin. He touches her belly. She is pregnant now. FANI (CONT’D) We have all we want. All we need. Nothing can change our love. We have our children. Our home. Each other. Nothing can take our happiness away. They pass under a wreath they have set above their door.
Yes, my wife. We’ll always have each other.
A child is born. A girl: Loisi. Her two older sisters loo in amazement. Franz turns to Fani and laughs. Their happi is complete.  10 a. 12 13 14
The next day they hear the ring of a little bell. The Pos appears on his bicycle with a letter. Franz reads it.
I've been called up. EXT. ORCHARD - RESIE, FANI’S SISTER a1 Fani is with her sister, Resie.
Just for training. A transportation unit.
Are you afraid?
Franz marches in step with a group of draftees.

After six months we'll be done with this training. Will the war be over? For now I can only be with you in my thoughts. It’s hard when I think of you -- when I remember our home. How is our baby? When I come home, I'll be surprised at how big she is... Have you considered using a horse? I don’t think your team of cows would be offended if you put them in retirement. ROSALIA, FRANZ’S MOTHER 13 Franz's mother, Rosalia, helps Fani load a pig into a car Fani is courteous to her mother-in-law, but Rosalia answe with a certain degree of distrust and suspicion, as if sh imagined Franz had married beneath him.
Fani reaps a field of fresh grass, with Resie and a famil neighbors.

Your mother helps me in the fields. It’s no good when we have to rely too much on the neighbors, always asking for help, and thanking them. The Strohofers have been kind. (she thanks the neighbors) The pig almost didn’t fit in the car. Only a boy came for it. It weighed 326 pounds. There was a wedding at the church. (a happy bride outside the church) I've finished tilling the oats. At the start, I had a hard time with the potatoes. It brought me to the point of tears. She puts hay up in the barn.
Fani feeds the children and puts them to bed.

Rosi is always asking about you. When we're going to bed, she says, “Papa's locked out!” At meals, “Save some for Papa.” If I get up at night, “Is Papa home?” Her sister tells her, “He'll bring sausage!”
The older girls play with Loisi, their new sister.

You know how the children bring me joy. A feeling of good fortune comes over me here, so that tears flow from my eyes, when I think of them, and you, and our reunion. You're doing so much. When I come home, there'll be no more work for me. I’1l become a babysitter! She scolds the girls when they get into mischief, as ofte they do.  17 18 EXT. J FARM a7 Fani washes the cows. She churns milk into butter. She gathers a wagonload of straw. She lays the hay out in windrows to dry.

I have to scold the girls. They argue terribly. They're always demanding my attention. Maridl hits Rosi, who says “You're bad.” Then Maridl says, “I’m good,” and Rosi says, “I’m good, you're bad.” Maridl pulled a leg off of Rosi’s doll and said, “Now the other one comes off, too!” Rosi wanted to go to the doctor to get the leg put back on. (a man in a dark forest) When Sterz is done with his work he goes into the forest and weeps. Toni Strohofer is always hungry. (a hungry man, stealing beets) I could use your help washing the cows. They’re always pleasant in the morning when they eat the leaves of the beets. Mathilde doesn’t wash them before she milks them, so I wash them myself. Mathilde; a lonely girl, knitting as she tends the sheep. FANI (0.S.) (CONT’D) I sold a few pounds of cabbage 3 pfennigs a pound. Frau Huber bought 44, Fani notices a man walking by, looking at Resie. FANI (CONT’D) He's interested in you. Look!
I don’t trust men.

Franz, with other soldiers from his unit. He sees how they defer to the Nazi captain, who lords it them, puffed up with a sense of his importance. They watch newsreels of Nazi victories in the West, show a bedsheet strung from a clothesline.

Much beloved wife! I am grateful for every word you send. Hopefully, winter won't come too soon. The farmers have their beets still in the field. Are you glad we don’t have beets? Franz listens as his comrades roar with delight at the misfortunes of their neighbors. Bewildered French peasant gaze at their German conquerors, ask them for food or fue
The children are older now. Loisi has learned to crawl. Franz's mother holds her in leading strings.

Loisi is a little pest. She always wants to be held. Rosi wanted to take your picture to bed with her tonight. You were supposed to sleep beside her. I told her that when father comes home, he will. She answered that father is already home. They gave your photo so many kisses. Rosi recognizes you, but Maridl simply said, “Man.” This morning, I was picking up the piglets. Szailer was there. The calf is now five weeks old. We worked hard this past week, spreading the manure. Toni stott was given 4 months in prison because he spoke out. He opened his mouth too wide. You'll not do the same. Those who speak out lose their leave.
Franz speeds down a road on his motorcycle in a military overcoat.
Dearly beloved wife! I was delighted to hear from you.  21 22

Hopefully the straw will not run out too early in the spring. You must use it sparingly. Have you greased the scythes and hung them up? Warm greeting from your loving husband, Franz. Many warm greetings to Mother, too, and to the little ones. See you again Franz watches an officer swagger and shout. A cadet, pass by, gives him a Hitler salute. Franz looks away, pretends to see.
Fani and Franz’s mother whitewash the house.

Besenbock will be called away. We must send him a goose. (the girls scuffle) Loisi is a dear sparrow. Always trying new things. She doesn’t go far yet. At most a step. She flutters about and falls. Then she is up again. She keeps your mother busy. She wants to be in every scuffle, though she always gets the worst of it. I feel badly for her, and I cannot help her. Her sisters are always the same rascals. Tomorrow I’11 do the cultivating. Hopefully, 1/11 hit no hard spots. I have a fear of such places. Fani works in the fields, spreading manure with a pitchfo Fani greases the scythes and hangs them up in the barn.

While on maneuvers, Franz meets a fellow soldier a few ye younger than himself. His name is Rogowski. There is no pretense about this man. He is kind, generous honest, and endlessly optimistic. He lives in the moment forgetful of the past, with no thought to the future. Rogowski’s face wears the innocent expression of a child, like a child everything he says or does is spontaneous an genuine.  23 24 25 Franz wonders how he lives as he does. Franz's unit is bivouacked by a lake. After early morning calisthenics, they learn their weapons. Franz plunges his bayonet into a straw dummy.

It need not be that everything in this world comes about as we want for ourselves. We don’t see the future. It may be a good thing that we don’t. Let’s resolve to begin the new year in confidence and good cheer. I have a few oranges for you. Speak with Schirk. They have the best oats. Whether our oats are also among the best is a good question. Concerning the butchering of the swine, do not wait for me. Fani and Franz’s mother prepare a sow for butchering.
A Sergeant takes Franz aside.
Lucky man! You've been let go from military service -- to manage your farm! France has surrendered. We'll have peace now.
Franz returns to Radegund. Home! He greets his neighbors he passes through the main square on the way back to his farm.
Fani and the children rush out to greet him.
You see? We just had to pray. They celebrate. Franz dances for the children. In the win a light burns past dusk.  26 27 28 10.
A few days later, Franz comes across a neighbor in the village square, a farmer named HESSLER. His friends are consoling him. There has been some unexpected event.
Hessler, what is it?
I've been called up. We thought there would be peace, but this war goes on. I don’t know why. His friends look at each other. Their eyes dart left and right.
Shhh. They pat him on the back. It could happen to anyone.
Franz questions his friend. Now they are alone.
Do you believe in what we’re fighting for?
A little. No. Not really.

We've invaded other countries. Stolen their land. And now we're doing it again. Aren’t they the heroes, who fight against us —- who defend their homes? (no reply) Is something right -- just because the crowd is shouting it? Hessler bows his head.

Passing through the woods, Franz sees a madman in the distance. Dishevelled, his hair and beard grown out; a ma look in his eyes, of fear or dread. It seems the poor fel had not expected anyone to pass this way. He looks at Fra for a moment, then slips off, into the darkness of the tr  29 30 31 11.
Fani can see that Franz is holding something back.
What is it? (after a pause) Toni opened his mouth too wide.
I wouldn't do anything that would bring you reproach... He looks in on his children. He kisses them as they sleep
To have a good husband -- a home -- they’re enough to make you happy... To love and be loved is the greatest happiness on earth.
Franz wakes up with a gasp. He lights a candle. Fani look him, startled.

I had a dream. I saw my father. I asked him what it was like in death. Could he tell me? He shook his head... Then I saw a train -- a wonderful train -- coming through the mountains. The locomotive was powerful -- dark —— it drew the children. They ran to it and weren’t held back. You couldn't see where it was going —— just the trees and fields, flashing by.
A train. A black locomotive. Coal is shovelled into the furnace. The tracks weave in and out. Pistons drive the engine forward: an overwhelming, relentless force.
Then a voice -- the voice said “This train is going into darkness!” I think it was a message.
32 33 34 12. Franz on his motorcycle, the wind in his hair, the lovely sense of being free of all constraint, rushing on
The next morning, at breakfast:
Those other men were like brothers.
The neighbors debate with Franz.
Who are you? Even the Cardinal ordered us to pray for Hitler -- to ring the bells on his birthday. Fly the swastika from the steeple. You forget.

You can’t blame the Cardinal for that. He hoped, by doing it, that the regime would be more tolerant toward the church. But now the priests are sent to concentration camps. Church processions banned. Mass on feast days, even Christmas, prohibited unless the feast falls on Sunday! We don’t have a say. It’s them up the hill that decide our fate. 32 3300 Officials from a fortress near St. Radegund wander throug the street, singing.
34 The fortress, far away. Seat of the military authorities, sits on a high hill, overlooking the valley below. It sta alone in the dusk.
What do you say, Franz?  35 36 37 13.

Franz wanders through the fields, disturbed by the sense a decision may soon be required of him, one that will put happiness of his family at risk and set him at odds with village, which he has loved since he was a boy. Out in the fields, a crucifix stands on a pole, a gabled above it to shelter it from the snow. Uncanny. It stops h in his tracks. The figure on the crucifix looks down at him in silence. Franz turns away, embarrassed. The path wanders on throug the fields of barley. But he cannot leave. He looks up ag takes off his hat. There is no one else in sight. The fie thrum with crickets. Franz takes off his hat, afraid. There are monuments to p everywhere in these mountains. So incongruous. What is it now finds in that face? Franz can tell no one. Especially not those closest to hi He cannot tell his wife.
One afternoon, Franz is cleaning up the church when he co upon a painter, a stranger to these parts.
I’m here to touch up the ceiling. Franz watches the stranger mix his paints. Above them, on ceiling, spreads a pleasant view of the heavens.

They look up and imagine that if they'd lived back in his time, they wouldn’t have done what the others did. They would've stood by him. They wouldn't have run. His friends did, though. They would, too. As the painter is talking, scenes from Franz’s life flash through his mind:  38 39 40 aL 42 14.
Franz sows a newly-ploughed field.
And I -- do I imitate him? No, I live off his life. I make a living by presenting him.

Franz works with his neighbors, remembers how they help e other here, neighbors depending on each other, like a fam and drawing closer to each other because of it. What else is there in life but getting closer to each oth
Others will look at this picture, and think that sympathizing with him -- being moved by his story -- will benefit them in the beyond.
Franz cuts wheat with a scythe, stopping from time to tim sharpen it with a whetstone he carries on his waist.
They’11 count themselves lucky that they didn’t live in times like ours, when your life might be demanded of you.
Franz threshes the wheat by hand.
Instead of suffering for the truth, I paint it.
The girls leap down from the hay loft onto the fresh stra
I turn the suffering of the brave into my livelihood. So people can look up from these pews and dream!  43 44 45 46 47 4g 49 15.
Fani pulls a loaf of bread out of the oven.
A hen shelters her chicks.
Franz cranks up the counterweights for the clock in the b tower.
I paint this comfortable man. A halo over his head. Some day I’11 paint the true one.
Franz rings the bell. Its sound rolls out through the fie
Franz looks on a procession. The men carry banners and statues. A statue sits on a platform, set aside, ignored, seemingly looking on, with what emotion he cannot tell.
Franz remembers a man bent over a fresh grave by the chur weeping in the driving rain, spreading an umbrella to kee the water from soaking down into the freshly-turned sod.
Fani in the fields, bent under a load of hay. She goes quietly about her tasks. Franz comes forward and kisses her. She wonders what has moved him to, out here in the open, just now.

can I do anything for you? She shakes her head.  50 51 16. He sees his mother, her arms hardened by a life of ceasel labor, like the limbs of an old tree that has passed thro many a storm. He plays with the elder two girls, whom he has put up int tree to pick apples. They look down at him from the branc and laugh. Their little sister hugs his knees, clamoring be picked up. Franz takes Fani’s hand.
I've always felt I didn’t have much to give you. But you took me. Even though T was a plain man.
I took the best man I’ve ever known. How could he have loved anyone who came short of that mar
Maybe others thought you could've done better.
Our children have a good father.

Images flash through Franz’s mind. A plow breaking throug the earth. Oxen. Patient, resigned, as he waters them. A gaggle of geese. None strays far from the others. Taking up a jug of water he has left to cool in a shock o wheat, some bumblebees fly out. He laughs as he retreats, swatting them away. Hot metal hammered out at a blacksmith’s forge. Dusk. Cattle in the back of a truck, on their way to the slaughterhouse. They stir and stamp, uneasily. INT. POOR WOMAN’S COTTAGE 51 Franz cleans the cottage of a poor old woman, an invalid. prepares a meal for her and cheers her with his conversat Someone rarely visited by others.  52 53 54 55 17.
Franz sits alone at the end of the day, drinking a beer. His neighbors are gathered nearby. The mayor. The blacksm and farrier. The policeman. The clerk. They sing old songs. Franz does not join in.

Radegund celebrates the Fasching festival. The people gather in a procession to drive out winter and prepare for the return of spring. They wear carved wooden masks, with crowns of flowers on their heads. They ring cowbells and dance. Why would he set himself at odds with those whom he has g up to cherish -- to whom he owes every consideration?
Franz passes a neighbor on his way home through the field
Heil Hitler! Franz ignores him. The neighbor frowns, waiting for an explanation.
Pfui Hitler! The neighbor looks around to see if anyone has heard, the goes silently on his way. Franz trembles all over; his he is in his throat.

Franz is tidying up around the church when he sees Fr. Fiirthauer, the young pastor of the parish. He has taken place of another priest, Fr. Josef Karobath, who, a few y earlier, was jailed for giving an anti-Nazi sermon, and subsequently banished from the district. Fr. Fiirthauer h good reason to be careful about what he says to this trou young man coming to him for guidance.  18.
Franz finishes ringing the bell. No one has come to mass today. They are alone.

Father -- I'm troubled -- if I’m called up, I can’t serve. We are killing innocent people. Raiding other countries. Preying on the weak. And the priests call them heroes, even saints —- the soldiers that do this.

Have you spoken with anyone else? Your wife? Your family? (Franz shakes his head) Don’t you think you ought to consider the consequences of your actions -- for them? Fiirthauer is wary of Franz, who might after all be a Ges agent, trying to see if he can extract some incautious wo from the priest.
You'd almost surely be shot.
Yes.
Your sacrifice would benefit no one.
You might be right. More I fear that I might do--
Wrong? Which is the greater wrong?
Speak freely, Father.
I have often wished that I might act on all I believe. But I have to think whom I might harm -- why do you look at me that way? You'd be taking your own life.  57 58 59 19.
If it were that —-
I'll speak with the Bishop about your case. A wiser man than I.
The priest takes Franz aside.

No Catholic who refuses military service will get any support from his spiritual leaders. You know that, don’t you? Can you blame them? For all they know you might be a Gestapo agent coming to trap them with your questions -- to lead them into an act of treason: To bring the wrath of the State down on our Church. They'd arrest any confessor who showed the slightest sign of sympathy for such inclinations. Franz searches his eyes. Is the priest really in sympathy with him and just can’t say so openly?
What can one do?

Now, as Franz passes through the village, it seems to him that his neighbors might not all be as happy, or as close he once imagined. That man in the woods. The cry of a lunatic woman he hear one evening across a field from a distant, darkened house swifts chase each other through the streets. The sky is f of their cries. EXT. COUSIN’S FARMHOUSE 59 Franz debates with his cousin whether he should refuse military service or not. He still hasn’t told Fani about qualms.  60 61 62 63 64 20. His cousin warns him not to speak about the matter with others in the village. There are jealous, angry people. A few. They might report him.
Franz has told her. She pretends this is a question they not face.
(after a silence) They won’t call you up. They need farmers. How else are people going to eat? INT. GIRL’S BEDROOM 61 They look at the girls asleep in their beds.
Ask, and you'll be answered.

Later, Fani prepares their bed and lays out his clothes. seems that she is making every effort to be kind and thoughtful, as though it were suddenly clear to her how precious her husband is to her, though her devotion to hi has been more than apparent already.

The Postman rides by on his bicycle, rings his bell and waves. Franz and Fani wait in fear and suspense every tim appears. He might deliver the same induction notice to Fr that his neighbor Hessler received.
Mother and son muck out the stalls.
what is it, mother?
Will you not spare your family? Do you hate your wife? Your children?  65 66 21.
No.
Did I bring you into the world for this?
Who's been talking with you?
How would she maintain the farm? With three young children. How would she plow?
Franz and Fani weed the orchard.
I went up to the mountains. They tell me what to do. The river does.

Franz has come up to the high mountains on his motorcycle There is a sudden silence when he shuts the engine off. High above stand the inaccessible peaks. The eternal snow rock. Below, the peaceful sound of a river, flowing nearb distant cowbell. The bluebells and vetch. Clover. Fireweed. Negligence; vacancy. Peace. Why not always? 0, for the wings of a dove! To fly far from trouble and grief! To his wife Franz presents a face of confidence and stren but inwardly he is assailed with torment, doubt and fear. From time to time we hear him inwardly expressing those feelings or recalling his past, to strengthen himself aga them.
My wife! You seemed like someone come from heaven. Humble. Kind. Through your eyes you sent a sweetness into my heart.  67 68 69 70 22.
You make me feel I have no enemy in all the world.
Fani’s sister takes Franz aside.

You took Fani’s happiness into your hands. She might have had other men. Not many besides you would think it a duty to add to their troubles this way. An image of the onrushing train passes through Franz’s mi
Franz and Fani have come to Linz to meet with the Bishop. They look up in awe as they enter the cathedral. The orga is practising a hymn.
Franz paces back and forth. Bishop Fliessen has kept them waiting for more than an hour.
The Bishop will be with you shortly.
Franz bows to the Bishop, who holds out his hand and, aft some pleasantries, moves quickly to business.

You have a responsibility -- to those within your private circle. Your family! Have you had a personal revelation from above? Was your conscience told to ignore the instruction of those responsible for your spiritual guidance?
I’m not sure.  23.

Not sure? I have a responsibility for the souls of your parish. It weighs heavily on me. I wouldn't be able to sleep were I either to keep silent -- or to speak out at the wrong time. Each of us must fulfill his duty -- willingly, loyally -- devote himself wholly to the service of his Fatherland... You know the words of the Apostle: let every man be subject to the powers placed over him,
And if our leader is -- a monster — - what does one do?

Our home’s at stake. Our people Be a man. Be strong... Our Leader knows war's horror. He himself was a soldier at the front. He tried to spare Europe from this conflict. But there was no avoiding it. Our enemies would make us slaves. oA INT. WAITING ROOM 71 Fani paces back and forth. When Franz comes out of the consulting room, he looks sad, or fearful

(in a whisper) I think he was afraid -- that I might be a spy. He said we have to obey. But that was in other times. When there were clergy who could be obeyed -- They don’t dare commit themselves. Or it could be their turn next. (later) They're flesh and blood, as we are. They can be weak. Maybe they’re even more tempted.  72 73 74 15 76 24.

Franz sees a group of monks tending a garden, smiling and chatting amiably. It seems they have no trouble with thei conscience. They live unperturbed by the world. Fani wraps her arms around him -- determined to support h not to insist on herself, but they do have three girls. Perhaps he will be exempted if ever he is called to milit service, or assigned to a hospital job. Perhaps he would accept such a position. Perhaps he won't be called at all
Images of Hitler, his face half-seen.
What difference will it make? He'll go on doing as he pleases.
They walk home in silence, Franz’s heart full to bursting
You didn’t make the world the way it is.
The girls run out to greet them. Rosalia looks on.
They are working in the fields when Franz’s mother turns him.

Good children obey. Their mother and father only want what’s good for them. They know it. If they work hard, they can buy a house with a garden —- live happily to the end of their days. (after a pause) A man brings his wages home to his wife.  1 78 25.

She puts them away, so that if ever they get sick, they can be nursed at home and won't need charity -- to raise their children or live into old age. People get what they deserve. Bad workmen come to bad ends. Fani glancing up -- sees a sow’s carcass, hanging from a outside the barn.

Franz trembles inwardly. What does his honor require of h It seems that no one can tell him the answer. He alone mu decide. Never has he felt so alone -- he who has always b so close to his family, his neighbors.
Franz sits in the beer garden, surrounded by friends, including the Mayor and the Policeman.
He got us into this war. The young men are gone —-
He did what he had to. He wasn’t content to watch his nation go under. He saw what we'd become. No destiny. Everyone chasing after comfort, success. No ideals.
.+.Breaking into homes! Tearing the earrings off women’s ears. My mother’s old. I hope she dies soon.

People saw that a fraud had been perpetrated against us. We found out that liberalism is a sham. Democracy. A mask for the commercial spirit. If we don’t lift the youth out of this swamp, they’1l drown in it. The Mayor is a member of the Nazi party. Franz has looked to him since he was a child. No ones dares to contradict  79 80 81 82 26.

Let's be glad democracy has died. See where it led us! To deadlock. Paralysis. Slaves of the rich! It has no strength to stop the crisis. Hitler is a new era. A new truth. (turning to Franz) Your father would have stood here and told you the same. He was in the war. He fought! What did he die for? In the trenches! The mu
The Mayor addresses a gathering of men in SA uniforms.
Flame, teach us! Light us! Show us the road! There’s no way back! Flame, ignite! Hearts, burn!

The Féhn blows over the fields -- a dry, burning wind, th melts the snow and clears the skies. Avalanches are loose The risk of fire is great. Everyone is on the alert, in a state of nervous expectation.
The snow looks clear. We might be able to send the flocks up early.

Franz debates what he should do. Omens of death flash thr his mind; an open door, a curtain beyond which he cannot a scythe cutting through the hay, the Salzach’s far shore Evil takes on so many disguises. His conscience is restle He vacillates. No one can give him any advice in these circumstances, even his own bishop. All that was familiar to him now seems far away.

Men in Nazi uniforms have come by the house to seek his family’s contribution to a collection they are making on behalf of the war effort.  83 84 27. Franz looks at them, says nothing. The men go away; astonished. This will set tongues wagging.
Franz hears a knock on the door. He opens to find the May standing before him.
You have refused to contribute to our collection on behalf of the veterans! Their families! This has clearly fanned the flame of suspicion in the community.

That is not like you. (after a pause) I also hear that you have refused to accept the family allowance, and other subsidies, that the State would generously have provided you. Why? Are you afraid to fight? Your father. A brave * man. You never knew him. You were just a boy. I know what he would * expect of you. Fani listens from the next room, alarmed.

Franz holds his hands out to the youngest girl. She teete towards him. It hasn’t been long since she took her first steps. From up in a tree, the older two girls drop apples down t their mother. She catches them in her apron. Franz walks by the Salzach. The river flows peacefully al whispering, murmuring -- what? What does it tell him? He wishes for some oracle; clear voice. *

He bows his head in the field with his wife as the angelu rings in the Tittmoning church, to the west. * They dig up potatoes, tiny figures in the vast landscape. Fani sings as she works. Peasant faces. Baked by the sun.  28. Their hearts cringe at the sign of the Postman, who rings bell as he rides by and gives them a friendly wave. They not comfortable until he is gone.
