The authorities might hear of her protests. She might end as her husband has. What would become of the children? The villagers ostracize her, more from fear than from dis or disapproval. She remembers telling Franz:

My husband! I want to die with you -- together -- but I have to live - - for the children! Officials from the fortress stop at the Gasthaus on their travels. Free from the eye of their superiors, they drink flirt with the barmaids, strut about. Rosi brings her mother an apple.
Rosi has set aside a beautiful apple, which I am supposed to send you, if I may. The girls went today to see the pony at the Schirks.  145 146 57.
Resie was glad to get out of the house. The children are too playful for her. The girls play with a pony that belongs to some neighbors
Loisi said to tell you she wants you to come home to play.
The villagers carry willow branches decorated with ribbon fruit and cookies to the church. Children, singing, lead way.
Palm Sunday our little ones went in the procession with the other children. Each held a willow branch. Fani sees other women on the arms of their husbands.
Franz turns in circles in his cell. He closes his eyes. H wants to pray, but he cannot; his anxiety is too great. H continues to pace, in torment.

Dear children, I’m grateful for the violets which you sent me. T can see you don’t forget your father who doesn’t forget you and would love to be with you. However, the heavenly Father wants to have it otherwise. Thank him that he has sent me a good wife and you a good mother. Always have love for your mother. Obey her. You can’t run outside with bare feet. O my wife, I know you fear for me, but my burden is light. When I compare my suffering to that of other people, I see that mine is the smallest of crosses. Many of the other prisoners suffer in silence, with no on write home to, no one who cares about them.  147 148 58.
How are things going with the haying? The apple that his daughter Rosi sent him rests on a tabl his cell.

As Franz walks in the courtyard, he looks over the walls the buildings on a street across the way. There people st live in some degree of freedom. He could join them. It wo take but a single word. One small act of relenting, and h might see his family again.
The Captain walks in a circle around Franz.
You feel no fear at following a line of conduct which leaves you in danger of the death penalty?
A man worth anything has only one thing to consider: whether he is acting rightly or wrongly --
Is your God stronger than the Fuhrer? (Franz does not reply) Why does He let him rule the world?
That is a mystery.

How do you know what is good and bad? Do you know better than 1? You seem to think there is a nobility in this. Who is this God that requires you destroy the life of your own with that of family? You think he wants your blood in order to satisfy him? Will it get you on his good side? Blood- drinker! (no reply)  59.

What have you done to him to make him send you this misfortune? (Franz nods; he will not deny it) Knowing that your Jesus suffered shouldn't make you want to suffer. He never sought it out. There’s a difference between the kind of suffering we can’t avoid and that we choose. You suffer for no reason. (no reply) Pride? Are you better than the rest?
He doesn’t cause anyone to suffer. He doesn’t tempt anyone. We tempt him.
You know his mind? He speaks with you?... Have you seen beyond the grave?

Franz thinks of Hitler. Newsreel images of the Fuhrer, untroubled, hailed by all. CAPTAIN HERDER (CONT’D) A private revelation! Would you not participate in any war —- or just this one? You have other plans? Is it because war isn’t the best way to solve our problems? Franz does not answer. CAPTAIN HERDER (CONT’D) You prefer to stay out of fights?
No.
Is it because you're afraid?
I’m afraid —- of the devil.
Am I the devil? A servant of his? I? I don’t feel that way. Christ is dead. Forsaken, as you'll be. He said so himself.  149 60.
You, too, will say, “I thirst.” You love a dead man -- more than your wife. Your children. You love a ghost.

You say we should do what the State wants because other people are responsible for what we do. No one wants to be accountable for the crimes done in our name. Responsibility is shifted from one person to another.
Are you mad?

You say, think of the times we live in. Well, those men and women in olden days, who put their lives at risk, because they wouldn’t. carry out Caesar's orders -- what do you say of them? Did they live in better times?
It’s one thing to take a stand on a big stage. But you are nowhere... You have no power.
Enough.

We live in a new world now. Night settles on the cell. The Captain is still with Fran single candle burns in the darkness. CAPTAIN HERDER (CONT’D) Are you afraid of death? The end? CU FRANZ & IMAGES OF DEATH (IN HIS MIND’S EYE) 149 Images of death flash through Franz’s mind: a shore, a ve a window sill, a fence in a pasture, an open door in the jail, a stairwell leading down into the darkness, a candl blown out.  150 151 61. In his mind's eye, from his memories of St. Radegund; oft analogies of death present themselves to him: a neighbor laboring at a plough, the ploughshare cutting through the earth, heaving it up. A sower, sowing. A harvester bringi in the sheaves, threshing the grain, winnowing it out. The Captain listens, silent.

Better to suffer injustice than to commit it. Nothing can harm a good man, in life or after death. I bear them no grudge —- they can’t hurt me. Who can harm us if we follow our conscience? They can only harm themselves. I suspect this that has happened to me is a blessing -- Dawn shines through the bars of the window.
The fresh green fields, in their spring glory. The fruit trees, blooming.

I can’t tell you anything about my future. I again had no trial this week. Dearest wife, we must not lose hope. If we can no longer celebrate together in the trusted family circle a joyful Easter in this world, then we await with full confidence the day when the eternal morning breaks. Then no one from our family will be missing. Then we can rejoice together. Forever. EXT. ST. R FARM isi Easter has come. The children pick flowers and roll Easte eggs. (According to this custom, the children roll hard- boiled eggs on a flat surface, the winner is the one whos egg goes the farthest.) Fani cleans the house. She embroiders towels and the hems the girls’ dresses. A clock ticks on the wall.  152 153 154 62.

I am in good health. I hope all of you are too. What fine weather! The fresh green of the grass is good for a person. Someone with freedom may not notice it. Outside, the villagers pass by, with fearful glances at t house of shame and doom.
Spring has come. You can again pick flowers and roll eggs. Thank Rosl for the apple which she sent me. I’ve saved it. Ros1 does a curtsey when her mother gives her this news.
fell the girls to be good so their mother doesn’t get put out with them.
As the children play outside, Fani leans her face against wall in despair.
The cities of Germany, in ruins. Those of Russia and Pola as well. Streams of bewildered refugees.

This week we finished the raking. We gathered wonderful straw. Your mother whitewashed the kitchen. The front of the house. All look beautiful. (to Resie) I’m sure it will work out. We just need to pray!
Franz’s mother has a way of taking over the house, shouldering Fani aside.
You go take care of the children. I'll stay here.  63.

Our primroses are almost completely dried up. It is too bad you aren't here to arrange everything. You are mich better at this. Zauner was by and said things are getting worse. She was inconsolable. Her husband goes back. Where they will send him is anyone’s guess.
He was never this way before. He was a fun-loving man till he met you! He danced! Then he got so serious. You -- with your religion! He used to laugh!
Fresh green shoots of wheat and barley have begun to appe in the fields. Fani and Resie cut hay. A sow eyes them warily.

We finished with the haying. Already it is so warm one can see the green shoots coming up! Tomorrow the sow will be butchered. I am happy about this. She has become more and more difficult. She would not eat the oats.
A cow gives birth.
The Tiefenhaler cow gave birth. The calf came out crosswise. We turned it with great trouble -- seven or eight people, pulling it out with much effort.
Pear and plum trees in flower. The girls scoop up the fal blossoms.  64.

Our fruit garden is glorious. Pear and plum trees already in bloom, the apple trees partly so. It is too bad you cannot be here. Be well. Warmest greetings to you from your loving wife, Fani. See you again!
Through Fani’s efforts to cheer him with news from home, follow Franz’s life in prison. He keeps his torment a sec from her. He does not want to disturb her. She has troubl her own.
One need not always think about what one cannot have at the moment. Dearest wife, I cannot tell you the joy of these days. I am still a fortunate child. Heaven will not abandon us.
Fani and her sister ride their bicycles down a road by th river.

Resie and I rode our bicycles to Altétting. Our trees -- the pear and apple trees, the plums -- are blossoming here more strongly than ever before. How beautiful it is when I go walking with the children -- sad you cannot be with us to marvel at it all. It would be doubly beautiful if you were.
Ganshanger, a neighbor, catches his fingers in a grinder.

Ganshanger cut off four fingers in the feed grinder. He was on leave from the front. He shouldn't have been working on a holiday. The police showed up. He is now under suspicion for self-mutilation.  161 162 163 65.

People are speaking much about it all. Poor man -- whether he did it to himself or not! The police sneer at Ganshdnger roughly. It is as though t felt obliged to make a show of their skepticism. Fani is out planting potatoes.
May I put some plants in your field?
Of course! She looks at the poor widow, stooped over them on her kne in the mud. A widow.
Fani, under her breath:
Spare him! 0, please! Tell me what I should do! She can tell Franz nothing of her anxieties, her doubts, though sometimes she cannot help herself.
Nor does Franz tell Fani of his ill-treatment, not only f the guards, but also by many of his fellow prisoners; ins he greets with courtesy, humility.

Girls, your Mother will scold you if you roll around too much in the grass. Your father greets you warmly. Do not forget me! Popular tunes -- sentimental songs -- play on the guards’ radio. The apple Franz’s daughter sent him sits uneaten, as thou he wished to keep it as a remembrance of his home.
Dawn breaks outside his window. The birds sing.  164 66.

Dear wife, I still can’t say how my future will unfold. What comes next is seldom better... And still, now begins the month of May, the most beautiful month. Nature does not notice the sorrow that has come over the people. A blackbird appears on the window ledge.

At dawn, we can hear blackbirds singing loudly outside our windows. They seem to have more freedom, and to know more of peace and happiness -- though they are only unreasoning animals -- than we humans do -- we who have the gift of understanding... (over the blackbird’s song) It should not sadden us if we must do without many things and give up what our hearts desire when we may be rewarded a thousandfold in eternity. Let our hearts yearn for everlasting gifts... How does the grain look? One loves his home. Greetings to our neighbors!
Two guards enter Franz‘s cell. Without a word of explanation, they shackle him hand and foot, then drag him roughly down the corridor, outside to waiting car. Where is eternity now?
Franz asks an officer who is accompanying him for permiss to write a letter. The officer, a Captain, nods. Kneeling down by the locomotive, Franz jots down a few words.
Dearest wife! I leave for Berlin at 10:13 AM. Have no concerns about me. The locomotive steams and hisses. It stands like an icon overwhelming force.  165 166 167 67.
Franz sits next to the Captain, a polite man who seems on to want to be done with his distasteful duty.

This departure came as a surprise. I had no time even to say goodbye to my companions. The officer accompanying me is a pleasant man. My decision remains the same. During the interrogations, they wanted me to take it all back —— deny everything...
The train crashes through the countryside. The tracks wea in and out.

If things in Berlin should go bad for me, have no concern. Now I must close. It is almost time to leave. Greetings to Mother, to you, the girls and all. See you again! It is night when they enter Berlin. Franz turns to the Captain. FRANZ (CONT’D) Why are they bringing me here? To the Capital? The Captain shrugs. STOCK FOOTAGE - POVS ON BERLIN ["SYMPHONY OF A CITY”] 167 Franz marvels at the vastness of the great city. He has n before been outside his corner of Austria.

I arrived safely on May 4. If it had been a vacation, it would have been a lovely ride. The farms and villages we travelled through were beautiful. Though I am still removed from you, have no heavy heart because of me. You know under whose protection I stand. I trust.  168 169 68.
Franz bids farewell to the Captain. They have arrived at Tegel prison, on the outskirts of Berlin.
I hope that I haven’t caused you any inconvenience.
No, I was coming up in any case. Good luck!
Now, suddenly, things change.
You! When I say frog, you jump! The guards treat the prisoners roughly, especially during their first days. Franz’s silence in response to their bl only infuriates them the more.
On the way I caught a glimpse of the vastness of the city. All goes well for me here. It is a little different than back home, but one need not suffer here, and many things are better.

The guards shove Franz into a cell. He looks around. Ther a bed that folds up during the day, a small table with a glass on it. A towel, a jug of water. In the corner, a to bucket. There is also a small wardrobe and a lamp that ca only be switched on from outside in the hall, that goes o and off without warning. The blankets on the bed have a foul smell. He throws them into the corner.

I have a small closet of my own. Very nice... If one dismisses an occasional harsh word, one’s heart remains at peace. He sets his chair beneath the window. He looks out. Rain falling. He can see nothing of the streets beyond.  170 a7. 172 69.
You! No looking out the window. Get down!
Here we may write one short letter only every four weeks. But we can get mail as often as it comes. Packages of food are not allowed.

The prisoners are called out of their cells. Each wears a black jacket and black trousers with yellow stripes runni down the sides. As soon as his door is unlocked, each prisoner steps forw and announces his crime.
Jagerstatter! Undermining morale! EXT. YARD, TEGEL a7. The inmates are allowed half an hour on the yard. They mu keep a distance from each other and speak not a word.

If I had any idea that I would be taken from Linz without a trial, I would have invited you there for a visit. A trip to Berlin would now be too hard. If it is God’s will, we shall have a reunion with each other again in this world. If not, then we hope for it in the next world, where the visiting time will be somewhat longer than fifteen to thirty minutes.
Franz's life at Tegel falls into a routine. A guard points Franz out to the others:

No one is to speak to him. A prisoner weeps in the next cell. No one takes any notic  70. He cannot see how things are run in the building. He can guess from the incessant shouting of the warders. He is t nothing. From morning till night, he hears their foul oat Their ill-treatment of those being held for investigation penetrate his cell. Everyone is treated as a criminal. Th is no mercy for the innocent or merely accused, or those locked up for trivial offenses. GUARD (CONT’D) If you complain of being struck —- it is, of course, strictly forbidden -- the boss will never believe you. Only me. I can always find a colleague who will testify for me. Under oath! The tone is set by those warders who behave in the most e and brutal way. The whole cellblock resounds with their abuse. The quieter, more fair-minded guards are nauseated it. But they tend to be the subordinates, and exercise no real influence.

We ask for work. Games are forbidden. Even chess. You can’t make up your own board. Don’t try! The prisoners suffer from a lack of occupation, especiall those in solitary confinement. The only work that is give them is folding paper into envelopes for soldiers at the front. They often sit in the dark for hours at a time bec the staff are too lazy to switch on the cell lights. When they put out the little flags designed to get a guar attention, the guards shout angrily at them, and their li is not switched on.

My dear husband! Trust in the heart! If the spirit that sustains us didn’t sustain the world itself, then everything would be out of kilter. why would it abandon us? How could it? They are not allowed to lie on their beds before “the Las Post", so they have to spend the prior hours sitting in t dark. When, late at night, the air raids come, there are no shelters for the prisoners. Franz listens to the anguishe cries of the men trapped in their cells. The thud of the bombs.  Tl.

The pain will only make us better and bind us closer together. For that I’m grateful -- best of friends, my man! Why should there not be for us, too, a secret power unknown to us, steering our fate toward the best - = a power beneficent, consoling? Why would we despair? Their days last fourteen hours. He spends three walking u and down in the cell. It is strange to him that the peace composure that were supporting him can sometimes vanish suddenly. Then he finds himself trembling inwardly with f and doubt. It feels to him like an invasion from outside, if some evil power were trying to rob him of what is most necessary to his sanity.

Whatever you think best is what I, too, want. Even if you believe a total separation between us is what we really must have, I won't take it wrongly. The bond will go on and on, to all eternity -- and life is short! But -- because life is short, should we forfeit it? Oh, tell me, where will we find one another again? Darling, my beloved soul! Where can I find peace? Let me face my duties forget about myself, even if it should be ever so difficult.

(to Franz) It’s a job, like any other. No talking with the others. No. I can let you break the rules, or I can join you there. No. Better a live rat than a dead lion. When he walks in the yard he gets pleasure from watching ants on a small ant-hill, from the bees in the linden tre from the swifts and swallows that dart between the buildi chattering gaily. It strikes him that nature carries on its simple, open li without interruption. It makes him feel sentimental towar the world, though not toward the flies that flit about hi cell; they only seem eager for him to die, so they can ca on their business unopposed.  72. He stops to look at the remains of a barn swallow nest th some wretch has knocked down and left on the ground.

Love will keep us close, when we walk where we can’t see. Feel it with me. The highest love finds no peace on earth. To seek it would be wonderful -- to die with each other! Together! But we have duties in this world. He has no knife or fork. He eats his meals with a spoon.

Pain will only make us better — draw us closer to each other! There are so many things that he could never tell his wif that she would not understand -- that would alarm and sic her. So many times when the world seems nauseating and burdensome to him, when he wonders who he really is: the who writhes under these experiences and cries inwardly to heaven, or the man who seems composed and cheerful -- in control of himself -- and who allows a few others to admi him for it. The man who plays a part.

How I love this pain now! When it leaves me, when everything in me goes numb, how I long for it again. Only my tears can give me joy. What is this love of ours? At such times the evening sky, the birds, the clouds do n know him. Nor the two lovers, whose distant laughter he hears. Nor his fellow sufferers, asleep or awake, turning their beds, shifting in their chains, turning and twistin unable to find warmth or comfort. Only the tower clock se aware of him, as it strikes the hour, asking him what can matter whether one day turns into another. I thank you for all the happiness you have bestowed on me. Through you I've received more than I could ever have expected. I hope that I’ve been worthy of it. I would like to give you peace. But I owe you an account of all T feel. Fear overcomes me. I know that it should not. But our love is too deep for me to be able to deceive you. eee
173 73. It is so hard to keep a strong heart. Not to surrender to sorrow and despair! To hold your head high when everythin seems to be going wrong.
Never doubt my love! It will be

yours for all eternity! Who else can I tell my heart to -- my one, my only friend? * EXT. TEGEL COURTYARD - THE SHARP JUDGE - FRANZ’S POV 173 Franz sees a man in black evening dress -- in tails and a stovepipe hat. He looks as though he were on his way to a wedding or a ball.
who is that?

(whispering) The Sharp Judge! He cuts off your head! The Sharp Judge looks at them. Steadily. At one point he seems to smile. A strange figure of death; the last perso that a condemned man would see. *

This won't have been the last time I see you! I can’t think that! Let me hope! Why we suffer I don’t * understand. Will we know some day? I become so downhearted, so quickly. Afterwards, I don’t know how to help myself... For all eternity I will be true to you. Best of friends! May I yet be able to give you joy! I’1l see you again! No one will take this certainty from me. * Franz cannot tell Fani, but gradually he has been sinking into a spiritual darkness. At the depth of that darkness again meets Rogowski, the soldier from his training days, a fellow prisoner, but unlike Franz himself, as bright an optimistic as ever. They greet each other warmly, though Rogowski does not se quite to remember who Franz is.  174 175 74. Over the next several days, Franz observes how this extraordinarily happy man never complains, but treats everyone with an unfailing good cheer, including the guar Franz marvels at him. Rogowski notices his low spirits, and urges him not to grieve. “The dawn is coming,” he says, “Trouble lasts an hour.” OR: “Imitate the sundial, only count the pleasant days." Franz sees how he loves, every man equally: the Na his fellow prisoners, the cooks, a dog, and Franz himself
A siren is wailing. A fire has broken out in one of the buildings. As the guards rush to put it out, Franz talks a prisoner a few years older than he is, a revolutionary Serbia.

Have the meek inherited the earth? How far we are from having our daily bread! (walls) Don’t let your life be a show. No one’s watching. Just these walls. We sense his cellmate’s doubts are those which torment Fr himself. He does not say a word in contradiction. A loathsome world! Not a trace of mercy in their decrees. Not a trace of love or charity. Their shamelessness knows no limit. why give your life for them?
Fani works in the fields.

Greetings, beloved husband! The weather is warm. Almost no day passes without rain. The grass and the clover are beautiful... the grain grown up. I hope no hail will destroy it, though we fear the British with their firebombs. They say the planes are flying over the countryside to destroy our crops. It would be terrible. We would have nothing to eat.

176 177 75. Fani’s wagon gets stuck in the mud. Some women from the village, neighbors passing by, look at her coldly. They m no move to help. She is now ostracized in St. Radegund, w notable exceptions.
Fani and Franz’s mother go out at night in search of two calves that have escaped from the barn.

We had a scare on Thursday night. We saw, to our shock, that the two yearling calves were no longer in the barn. Nowhere to be seen or heard. You can imagine how upset your mother and I were. We set out to look for them -- found them at last at the Strohofers. It is terrifying to have to search for animals at night... I am always in pain for you. I keep you in my love. You’re so far away. I send you many kisses. Mother can no longer sharpen the scythe. No one can as well as you. One can go to Lang, but he is always in a hurry.

Rosalia and Resie take turns trying to hammer the scythe blade into sharpness. The banging works on Fani’s nerves. EXT. FOREST (ST. R OUTSKIRTS) m7 Fani and Resie gather wood from the forest. Rosalia helps she is able. The girls obey their mother more readily now though doing so might help to bring their father back hom

During this week we were in the forest. Together we cut down the brushwood. The children cannot understand why you are away for so long. They pray for you and are well-behaved. (buying pigs) I got some piglets from Mossbauer. Four weeks old. I held off for a time because they were expensive. Now I have paid 100 for the pair. Not bad, right? For the children I bought young rabbits. 2 marks each.  178 179 16.

The children are having great fun with them. We can breed them and make a profit. (driving calves out of the orchard) The calves are cute. But I must sell one of them soon. They eat too much. They have already devoured everything in the orchard. The clover, too. If only you could be home, dear husband. Yet many suffer greater blows (apples in the heights of a tree; Fani strikes them with a pole) We still have some apples which you have always enjoyed eating. I do not have much of an appetite because you cannot be here... and must suffer from hunger. With greetings from your wife!

head_text.subj: FANI, TRYING TO SELL HER PRODUCE 178

text: Fani has put a bright face on things for Franz’s benefit. When she goes to sell her produce, the villagers shake th heads. They will not buy from her. How will she support the children? when winter comes, wha then?
Franz is led into the presence of a lawyer, a handsome ma somewhat older that himself.

Friedrich Feldman! I’ve been appointed by the court -- to be your defense attorney. Feldman smiles cordially and takes some papers out of his briefcase. FELDMAN (CONT’D) We must make an effort to answer these charges. I understand that you have refused service in the Wehrmacht -- though you once trained with them, as a motorcycle driver, I believe. As I understand, your resistance is specifically to serving in combat.  1.
But I believe if you were to accept medical service -- work as an orderly in a hospital, that sort of thing -- they would probably drop these charges.
Would I be required to swear loyalty to Hitler?
Words! No one takes that sort of thing seriously -- But yes. He leaves off. He cannot be sure who might be listening
I can't
Why not?
It hurts my heart. My mind.
I've spoken in confidence with a member of the court. I think —- we could come to an understanding. In a hospital, you might do some real good.
Feldman waits for Franz to answer. He does not.
You're a stubborn man. See here, I’m going to leave this paper with you. Keep it with you... Sign, and you'll go free. He shakes Franz’s hand and leaves.
A man in dark civilian dress interrogates Franz, who has idea who this stranger is or where he comes from.
What you're doing is wrong. Admit it. We can move on.  78.

We can lessen the consequences.Given the state of the world, other people are making the same mistake. They feel confused, overwhelmed, sick. You aren't to blame. You aren't the cause of all the trouble in the world. He moves closer to Franz, careful to maintain eye contact with him, allowing him no chance to speak or, when he doe raising his voice above Franz’s own, or talking over him.

I see how you look at me. But I don’t believe in anything. I get by. (walking behind Franz) I believe in what I own. What I can touch. Feel. I hate death. He peels an orange. He points to the paper that would rel Franz from service in the military, and the officials themselves from a growing discomfort.
Sign -- and you'll go free.
I am free. Already.
Strange freedom! No, my friend. T can walk out that door. Into the street. I am free. Not you. He sees that Franz will not relent, and yet is assailed w fear and doubt.
This is what happens when you put honor above everything. What for? Will you be more innocent than everyone else? We’re soaked in blood. The whole earth is.
Yes -- it is awful!
Do I have any obligations? I’m obliged to do only what serves my interests. I was once like you. I learned pretty quick.  79.
(he claps his hands) You won't change the world. You have no power. The Fiihrer has power.
What kind?

Enough to determine if you live or die. (no reply) I'll bury you, my friend! 1/11 be walking around, playing with my children, when you're in the grave. Gone to land no one has come back from. You remember what Achilles said -- glorious Achilles -- when Odysseus met him in the underworld? Odysseus told him that no man had been more blessed than he. And Achilles said: “Don’t try to reconcile me to dying. I'd rather be another man’s slave, a poor peasant without land, and be alive up on the earth, than lord of all the lifeless dead. Give me news of my son instead.” That’s what he said. I'd rather be a slave in the sunlight, than a hero down here! A shadow! A shade! He shakes his head. A hard-necked peasant! No changing hi mind!
No more family. Children. Sunlight. No pretty music. Nothing. Night. Night settles on Tegel. Cries resound through the cellblo The heat is oppressive.
Tonight, again, there are air raids. As the sound of the bombers grows louder, there are cries of fear from the prisoners, locked in their cells.  182 80.
It is during a raid that Franz receives a visit from Fr. Heinrich Kreutzberg, the Tegel chaplain. The crunch of explosions can be heard in the distance.

You aren't responsible for their actions. You have no basis on which to reach a judgement as to the justice or injustice of this war. Your only responsibility is to meet your obligations to your family. Your people.
I don’t see things as you do, Father. We can’t remain silent in the face of evil. We have to confront it.
How? The Church can never make demands of its members that might alienate great numbers of them -- or provoke retaliation from the State.
I don’t want to take the slightest part in this war... Franz had expected consolation from the priest, a man of own faith.

I suppose you prove there’s -- an examination. That the exam can be taken. But who knows of this exam? Who can be expected to answer it? Overhead, the light falters, then goes out Franz’s children come to him in a dream. They hold out th hands, imploring him silently. One opens the door of his cell, show him the way out, the empty corridor, a stairwa beyond it. Then he sees, behind them, a man in a Nazi uniform, his f wrapped in a cloth so that his eyes cannot be seen, or anything of his expression  183 184 185 186 ei.
At dawn, Franz is dragged out of his cell, into the corri

I continue to find my situation quite satisfactory. Do not worry, my wife. It could be worse. I am still alone in my cell. Almost daily we have half an hour to move about freely. One can work in his cell as much as he likes making envelopes. And I can still pray for you. Here I can make a retreat.
Franz is led to a car in the courtyard below. He has no i where he is going.
Two guards drive him to the Reich’s Military Tribunal in Witzleben Street (Charlottenburg). He gazes out the windo others going about their daily lives.
May 24 I appeared before the Reich's Military Tribunal for interrogation. It was a long ride by car. The Tribunal is in Berlin, Tegel a little outside the city. The linden trees are in bloom.

Franz is led through the hallways of the Tribunal. His ha are bound in chains. FRANZ 0.8. Hopefully you've had more rain there than we have here. Otherwise it will be disastrous for the fruit. Stairways lead up towards and opaque skylight.  187 82. INT. REICH’S MILITARY TRIBUNAL 187 Franz is made to sit down on a chair in the middle of a large, drafty hall. The Court Martial convenes: The First Judge, Werner Leube two military officers; a prosecutor; a clerk, and Franz’s defense attorney Feldman. Banners with swastikas hang beh them. Judge Lueben opens the hearing.
Heil Hitler! Franz trembles at the name. The charges are read out. Aga them we hear Franz addressing Fani, as though in a continuation of his letter:
Be at peace... forgive each other.

After giving the personal details of the defendant, the Prosecutor reviews the indictment. Franz marvels at the strange hat Judge Lueben wears. He looks around at the ot people in the room, wondering what their lives are like.
You must be busy with the haying, and once again picking strawberries and blueberries. Soon you will be looking for cherries at Lang's.

Court-Martial of the Reich... StPL (RKA) I 98/43... Red list... In the criminal case against Jagerstatter, Headquarters Company of the Motorist- Replacement Division 17 in Enns, born on May 20th 1907 in Radegrund (Oberdonau)... Wehrmacht remand prison Berlin-Tegel... Judge- Advocate of the Reich Lueben. Air Force General Musshoff... Vice- Admiral Arps... Brigadier General Schreiber... as prosecutor: Judge- Advocate General Dr. Kleint, as records clerk: Court-Martial Inspector General of the Reich Wagner... The accused has been sentenced to death, deprived of army honors and of civil liberties...

After 8 years of primary school, he worked on farms and mining married, father of three children, aged 3 to 6 years... displayed the same negative attitude during his hearing with the investigator of the court of Division no. 487 in Linz as well as with the representative of the Reich’s War Advocacy.

No one shows much interest in the defendant, much less an trace of compassion. When, at the end, Franz is called upon to speak in his defense, he says nothing. Judge Leuben calls the members of the court into another for a short consultation. It seems they are uncomfortable with the situation that is being forced on them. They wou be glad if Franz were ready to accept service as a medic. would relieve their consciences of a burden they never as for.
The Judge steps into the room where Franz is held. Feldma showing discretion, steps away. The Judge indicates to Franz's guards that he would like to be left alone.
What are you doing, my fine fellow? Would you accept service as a medic? You wouldn't have to take up arms. Franz does not reply.

My son was in the Army. He went in when they called him. He had to suffer. He died in Russia. In the snow. He had a conscience. Are you proud of your virtue? Afraid of your conscience? Has it made a coward of you?
Do you imagine that anything you do will change the course of this war? That anyone outside this court ever hear of you? No one will be changed. The world will go on as before. You’ll vanish.

Drop away. Like a stone in the sea. If a man can’t benefit the world by his death, how can he decide to sacrifice his life? You're the guilty one. Not I. I didn’t make the world the way it is... It makes no sense to will more than is possible at any particular moment. Life’s hard enough as it is. You'll change nobody's mind. Your actions may even have the opposite effect of what you intend. Someone else will take your place. We want to save you. You have nothing more to say?... You know what it means.
I stand by what I've said. Franz says it in a trembling voice.
You'll have saved no one -- and damned yourself. The truth is, it’s you, not I, who pronounce the sentence. You, the judge.

Aren't you tired of the whole business? Isn’t this a self— inflicted torture? I suspect you have some false belief in the virtues of misery... suffering. 84. Lueben sees that he has gotten nowhere. And now it is he seems to tremble inwardly, aware that he is going to incu inescapable guilt in convicting a good man.
Do you judge me?
No. It's not for me to make your life harder for you. I don’t judge you and say, he is wicked, I am right. I don’t know everything.  5.

A man may do wrong, and not be able to get out of it -- get his life clear. Maybe he would like to go back, and can’t. That must be a bitter thing. But I have that feeling inside me, that I can’t do what I believe is wrong. That’s all.
You mean it?
Why would I say it, if I didn’t mean it?
I could set you free. He speaks with a growing desperation.
Even now, even now, something might be done. If not, the dreadful.
You send me to our Father.
He won't have long to wait.
The Tribunal has reconvened. Franz is distracted -— canno bring himself to pay attention to the reading of the document, until the verdict is announced

According to 60 KStVO. III... He thus became guilty of degrading military strength and has to be punished according to 5 paragraph 1 number 3 KSSVO. The criminal nature of his action will not be suspended due to consideration of conscience or his religious beliefs for legitimate (Section 48 MStGB)... Tegel, the accused is completely normal, there is no sign regarding diminished responsibility.  86.

There have been no known cases of mental - or hereditary diseases in his family... The crime of degrading military strength is punishable by death... Since the accused has proven through his actions that he is dishonorable, he will be deprived of civil liberties according to Section 32. And no public honor shall be given him, under penalty of law. Berlin, July 14th, 1943...
Feldman takes Franz aside and tells him, hurriedly:
Today they pronounce the sentence, but they still have to confirm it. It might be days, weeks. Sign the paper in your cell. You'll go free. I can work it out. Quietly, you know. I feel sure.
A Sergeant drives Franz back to Tegel.
You've been here for the last time. Now it goes to St. Peter! Eh? (when Franz does not reply) Aren't you afraid?
Franz is taken from his old cell to the third floor, wher these prisoners are kept who have been sentenced to death a condemned man, his legs will now be shackled as well as hands.
Now it will be your legs, too. I’m sorry. Now the light in your cell, we can’t turn it off. It will be on day and night. A naked bulb hangs from the ceiling.  87.

Images of Hitler, half-seen, flash through Franz’s mind. does such a man exist? But Franz did not create him. What business does he have standing against him -- a murderer totally unaware of his existence and whom he can do nothi to stop?

Saturday I sold a calf. we received 630 marks. I fetched the piglets from Moosbauer. Together they weigh 32 pounds, and they cost 80 marks. Not bad. We seldom have good weather, or we would be out. We've brought the hay in from the first meadow.
Fani works in the rain, spreading manure on the fields.

Warm greetings, most beloved husband, from your faithful wife, Fani. Greetings in God, who will make everything right again. Your mother’s feet are hurting. The work is often too much for us. My lungs are weak. So it is, yet there is always more work. She borrows a wagon from a neighbor.

I have a terrifying anxiety about the harvest. Your mother can no longer bear the heat. The grain is magnificent for reaping. I could use you. If only you could come home, for at least four weeks! Sixteen hours each day is no small thing. Wagner was here today and chose the wooden strips for the dung wagon. Till today we had no wagon. Ours was broken. The girls help as they can. Franz’s mother fusses at them not doing more. Loisi whispers in Fani’s ear.  88.

Loisi said that when Father returns, she’1l no longer sleep with me, but always with Father. I'd gladly lose her if you could be at home. Now we must rake leaves because we need the straw. The harvest comes nearer. Be well!
Franz studies the letter that sits on the table in his ce awaiting his signature.

It is not as difficult for me here as everyone at home may imagine. T remain in good health and hope that you do, too. He paces back and forth. His heart pounds in his throat. he so sure? Has he heard a voice? Does he hear it still? Might it be leading him, and his family, to their doom?
I know that you are interested in knowing whether my future has yet been decided. Be patient till T know. You need have no heavy heart about me.
Rosalia weeps over their fate. So unexpected! Undeserved! much unanswered pain!

And dear Mother, thank you for your kind words, which my wife has reported. I hope that you are no longer angry with me for my disobedience. It has not rained a great deal here, though there have hardly been two sunny days in a row. I hope the weather will be better for the harvest.
The children play outside.  198 199 200 201 89.

My dear little ones, do not lose heart if your father does not come to tell you stories. Today there are many children whose fathers cannot come to them now, nor will ever come to them again. Be well- behaved. I would have loved to see you wearing those garlands on your heads. From far away your father sends you warm greetings.
Fani has received a letter from the Postman. She comes to mother-in-law, reading it with alarm.
It's from his lawyer. He says that I should come to Berlin. They’ve condemned him to death! Why didn’t he tell us? We have to go! Right now! The lawyer says so: no delay. There still might be time!
Fani knocks on Fr. Fiirthauer’s door. The pastor opens to her in a state of great distress.
Fani and Fiirthauer have boarded a train to Berlin.

What will you tell him? Angles on the train: the steel rails; the villages flashi by; coal shovelled into the firebox; the fierce-burning fires. The locomotive; a blind, unminding force running i knows not where.

EXT. STREETS, CROWD (FROM “BERLIN: SYMPHONY OF A CITY”) 2 Berliners head to work, to their factories and shops. How is a man to stand up against the great Baal? It is an obscure battle, more exhausting than struggling with a tyrant, for no decisive point is ever reached. The strugg with the Many begins all over, each and every day.  202 203 204 205 206 90.
When Fani arrives at Tegel, she is told her husband is no there. She looks around in wonder as she and Furthauer ar led down a corridor to a visiting room.
She sees the other prisoners. She has brought some food f Franz, but she is told she will not be allowed to give it him.

She is left to sit in the visiting room for half an hour. Presently, a truck pulls up the courtyard. She goes to th window and looks down. When the truck comes to a stop, th back gate falls open. Some soldiers jump out and form a circle. Then Franz, in chains, is shoved out so roughly t he falls to the ground.
Franz looks up sharply as he hears his wife’s cry. He had idea that she would be visiting him. He looks frantically about him. It is as though her voice had come to him from another world.

Franz‘s chains have been removed. He is taken to the visi room, where he finds his wife, Fiirthauer and his defense attorney, Feldman. Franz is overcome with joy. He has long since reconciled himself to the fact that he might never see her again. Fa throws herself into his arms. One of the guards pulls her away. Franz listens in silence as Fani and Furthauer, advised b Feldman, urge him to sign a statement saying he will agre serve in the Army. (Improvised)
You're doing no one any good. Will you not abandon this senseless position? If you do, I’1l at once petition the court to stay the execution of your sentence.  gi.

But it must be done without delay Today! I’m sticking my neck out here. This could jeopardize my career -- if not my personal safety. Fani is heartsick to see those traces of hunger and suffe in Franz that he has attempted to hide from her.
(to Feldman) What will they gain by shooting him?
Tell your husband, not me!
Didn't he tell you that he would accept being assigned to the medical corps?
We begged him to do it. She turns to Franz. Did he prefer that she not know of th opportunity to save his life —- has he rejected it?

The charges would be dropped, I’m sure, if you just change your stand. I beg you to. The war may soon be over. You might never have to face a situation that would call on you to do what you oppose. Franz does not seem to hear, overjoyed to see his wife ag She gives up any effort to change his decision. She sees it would make no difference; he has already made up his m
You came.
Franz, you must. Don’t you see what's coming? Take the oath.
Is this why they let you come?
God doesn’t care what you say. Only what’s in your heart. Say the oath, and think what you like.  207 208 92.
Haven't you done as much as he could ever want?
Who are you to lecture me on my duty? Why have you come here -- to distress me and my wife! Leave us in peace!

The guards end the meeting. It has been just twenty minut Fiirthauer gives Franz his blessing. Franz gives Fani a f pieces of chocolate for the children. Tenderly, Franz takes Fani in his arms. The Guards look a each other. FRANZ (CONT’D) fell me you understand. Tell me you forgive me. So I can die.
Pretend -- pretend I do? No! But T love you. I always will. whatever you do! Whatever comes! Even... The Guards pull her away. FANI (CONT’D) Let me go. Take your hands off me.
Do what I say.
Fani and Fiirthauer board the train back to Austria. Musi comes in.

I’d meant to tell you so many stories about life at home, T forgot so much. You yourself were annoyed -- but the pastor meant well. Don’t lose heart! Warm greetings to you from your loving wife, Fani, who is concerned about you. And many kisses! Be well! See you agai
INT. FRANZ’S CELL ~ MUSIC 208 Franz paces back and forth, in fear and trembling.  93.

I wanted to give you all I had. You never asked for anything. It hurt that I had so little to give. Sunlight in you. Around you. Have I been so good to you? Have you missed life? Can you miss it, the way you miss a train? You, forgiving me. Where are you now? *
Fani sits on the train with Fiirthauer. It hasn’t yet lef station. Some children are playing in a vacant lot nearby
(haunted, shaken) I hope I didn’t upset him. I did.
You always said that if we lived a good life, we'd be happy! It seems that doing so might bring you suffering instead. Sorrow!

(after a silence) It is terrible to represent Christianity, as I do, and not * really to be a Christian. Not yet. * I know what one is. But if you set it forth in all its truth, people would revolt against it. This collar doesn’t protect me from hypocrisy. We've made the church * into the theater. Me, an actor! The world will have no benefit from my having lived. I will just have helped it go on deceiving itself. The world wants to be deceived. He looks at Fani in despair. *
Over Fani’s return home, we hear Franz's letter in respon to her visit:
You made a great sacrifice by coming here.  94.

It would have spared you much pain and expense if my defense attorney had not written to you. I still have not received a statement that my death sentence has been confirmed. To be sure, I received great joy from our reunion, but not from the fact that you had to make such a great sacrifice. It brought me pain that we could speak so briefly. I am not angry with the pastor. I ask his forgiveness for all my unnecessary words to him. I wanted to spare you the suffering that you've borne for me. Franz offers his food to another inmate; a man who seems never to have expected mercy from another human being. He receives Franz’s portion with suspicion and distrust, convinced that Franz is a fool.
You gave him your food.

Dear wife, do you believe that all would go well for me if I were to tell a lie in order to prolong my life? How our final hours will be, we don’t know. Or what struggles we must pass through. Back in Radegund, Fani reads Franz’s letter out loud to Resie, who though she believes all this was unnecessary, must admit:
He loves you. I love him for it. 211 INT. FRANZ’S CELL 211 The Guard finds Franz alone in his cell.

I’m just trying to be a father. Raise a son. Work hard. Up early. You think you're better than I am? Can’t call in sick on Monday. No holidays. Do my duty. So my family can slee, (slapping Franz's face) Turn the other cheek?
I stand by my brothers and sisters. Proudly. When my land’s in danger! You offend me.
why? The Guard steps on Franz’s hand.
How does that feel? You think I care? You think that if you look at me that way I’1l stop? Do you? Who can stop me?
No one.

I can do what I like with you. 95. You're nothing to me. Nobody would know. Care. Nobody lift a hand to stop me. I have power. Putting on airs! No one hears, my little friend! No one cares. Nobody's minding the store.

The guard attacks him, knocks him to the ground, and kick him in the mouth. GUARD (CONT’D) The Sharp Judge waits for you. They take off your shoes, socks. Tie your hands behind your back. Then no wife! No children! You offend me. What do you say now? Are you the wisest man in the world? Do your betters know less? A peasant! He strikes him again, stung that Franz will him. GUARD (CONT’D) It’s good manners to scream. To beg! To say: “Mercy, Father! 1/11 pray for your good health!" say it! “Please, stop! I worship you! The ground you walk on.” Don’t look around. There’s no God here. Inside these walls! Where? Where do you see him? I'm your God. not plead with  96.
(to Fani) So much can change. So much goes differently from what we would like...
Do you forgive me?
Yes.
How dare you? He strikes Franz in the eye.
Didn’t think I'd do that, did you!
I’m not afraid of you. He strikes Franz again.
Does anyone see? Are you a man? (holding Franz to the wall) Your God doesn’t -- hear you. He's put you in our hands. Alone. You're alone!
No.

You look in my eyes when you talk to me. Bad manners! Look down! Franz will die with no expectation that his sacrifice wil make the slightest difference to anyone. For his neighbor the refusal of army service is an act of folly, a sin aga his family, his community, and even his church, which has called on no one to refuse military service. He knows that, beyond his family and community, his death will go entirely unnoticed, have no impact on the Nazi movement or hasten the end of the war. He will be forgotten. Who might remember or care about th vain gesture of an uneducated farmer? One more name among millions whom the Nazis have executed.  212 213 214 97.

Images of death crowd into his mind: the open cell door ( could walk out), a stairwell leading down from the cellbl into the darkness, the hay-scythe cutting through the gra and, last of all, the train from his dream of years ago.
Today the sentence was confirmed.
Fr. Kreutzberg sits across from him.
Others have done the same. Last year. Franz brightens at this news. Kreutzberg speak softly, to avoid being overheard.

I used to think that if you loved others rightly, all would go well for you. Did it go well for Christ? Now I see: if you want happy days, don’t get involved with him. It brings trouble. He looks at Franz in awe.
The Prosecutor has come out to Tegel to read Franz the document confirming his death sentence. He explains that next day the judgment will be carried out. Kreutzberg and doctor are also present.

The criminal nature of his action will not be suspended due to his beliefs (Section 48 MStGB)... The accused is completely normal, no sign that would... Later, Fr. Kreutzberg nods at the letter still lying on t desk. Franz has only to sign it.  215 216 217 218 98.

Franz spends his last night on earth overwhelmed with ang and doubt. In the morning, two guards come to fetch him. His shoes a socks are taken off, his hands bound behind his back. All just as he was told it would be.
...Sufficiently informed about the duties of a German soldier... tenanciously refuses to fulfill his patriotic duty as a soldier during Germany’s struggle for survival.
The prisoners look down in silence as Franz is led to the that will take him to the execution site at Brandenburg Gérden. Several other condemned men, strangers, crowd into the ba with him.
Fani has received a last letter from Franz. She reads it the children.

Dearest wife! And all my loved ones! This morning, at approximately 5:30, I had to get dressed immediately, for a car was waiting. I went with other condemned prisoners on the ride from Tegel to Brandenburg. We do not know what will happen to us. At noon someone told me that the verdict would be confirmed at 2:00 p.m., and that it would be fully enacted at 4:00 p.m.
The condemned ride in silence. One of them, a 19-year-old boy, looks at Franz as though to ask: “Will I not escape?  219 220 99.

They descend from the truck at Brandenburg prison. At the of a courtyard stands an old garage. It is here that the executions take place. Briefly, in the distance, the Sharp Judge appears -- dres like a dandy in tails and a top hat, and smoking a cigare The condemned are given writing materials.
Who do I write to? My family’s gone. All take courage from Franz’s example.

I want to write all of you a few words of farewell. I am deeply grateful for everything that you have done for me in my life —— for all the love and sacrifices which you have shown me. And I ask you once again to forgive me for everything that I have made you suffer... I ask everyone else, whom I at some time have pained and hurt, to forgive me. Especially the pastor with my words as he visited with me. It was not possible for me to free you, dearest wife and mother, from the sorrows that you have suffered for me.
Fani reads Franz’s letter to the children.

Give my warm greetings to my dear children. Do not forget me in your prayers. And may we see each other soon. Greetings to all of you before his last journey from your husband, son, and father, son-in- law and brother-in-law. Heart and my heart be one, bound for time and eternity. Rosi, the eldest girl, sees her mother in distress. What she doing, hiding her face that way?  221 222 100. The younger sisters play, oblivious, as with a solemn awe Rosi gets her first glimpse of human suffering and wonder what may lie ahead for her, and for them all.

Fr. Kreutzberg offers to read to Franz, but he shakes his head, preferring to sit in silence. The pastor marvels at how Franz remains at peace through final hours; calm, prepared. No word of fear or complaint passes his lips. His eyes shine with a strange joy.

The condemned are led to the outbuilding that in the past used as a garage. There are still a few old tires lying around, wrenches, the rusted parts of a disassembled transmission. The men -- 18 of them -- stand in a long row, several met from each other. In front of the execution chamber there bench, where three may sit at a time.

They call it the Devil’s Bench. The humor goes unappreciated. As each man stands up to be into the garage, Fr. Kreutzberg comes to him, gives him a cross to kiss and prays with him. The condemned man is led by two Sergeants into the room. There is a small table, on it a cross between two burning candles. Behind the table stands the Prosecutor, a clerk the court, a doctor and the priest. Two executioners step up behind the condemned man, his personal details are read out once again, with the judgme against him. Across the whole room hangs a black curtain. It is just a they described it to Franz. In front of the curtain, the Sharp Judge. The Prosecutor calls out:
Sharp Judge, fulfill your office! The curtain rises. The scaffold becomes visible. The guillotine rises above it. Then the curtain closes
223 224 101. It happens that Franz finds himself next to Josef, who, trembling, turns his back to the instrument, looks up int Franz's face and thanks him:
I'm not afraid of anything while I’m with you. Not if they make it quick.
They will. They speak as if they were alone. Eye to eye, heart to he at one point hand in hand. Strangers who have come togeth on life’s dark highway, to make their way home together.
What do you see? He is struck by the strange look in Franz’s eyes. JOSEF (CONT’D) * You comfort me. I’m so ignorant. May I kiss you? Has the moment * come?
Yes. He kisses Franz on the cheek. The young man’s hand does n tremble. There is a bright constancy in his face. He goes first, and is gone. *
Be strong, my wife! I'll wait for you! He steps forward. *

Forgive me! You have been good to me, and to my son. And I haven't been good to you!  225 226 227 228 229 102. She kisses Fani’s hands.
Mother! Children!
Fani throws herself into her sister’s arms.
I don’t understand!

Against the Prosecutor’s order that there be nothing done honor Franz’s memory, a neighbor goes into the church and grasping a rope that hangs down from the ceiling, in a sm act of defiance, begins to ring the bell, as Franz once d The Mayor looks up from a chair in his garden. Unmoved, indifferent. The Policeman weeps, alone.
The tolling of the bell reaches out through the fields, gathering the villagers into a single body.
The fortress stands in silence.
Fani speaks with Fr. Furthauer outside the rectory, consc of the glances of two villagers in the distance.

I’ve lost a good husband. A good father -- for my children. our marriage was one of the happiest in the parish. People envied us!  230 103. FANI (CONT’D) Our beautiful union was lost. Already I look forward -- to where no war can ever separate us again!... With great respect, from the depths of my heart, I wish you good for all you’ve done —- for my dear husband!
She turns and goes away.
Fani and Resie work their way through a field of barley, cutting the stalks with a sickle and laying them out in windrows.

I thought you just had to be good. Wasn't he? Franz! Her sister takes her hand. FANI (CONT’D) A time will come when we'll know what all this is for -- why there’s all this suffering. And there’1l be no mysteries. Well know why we live.
Far away they hear singing. The neighbors are working in their fields. The life of the land goes on. ‘THE END  Best Picture Produced by GRANT HILL, p. DARIO BERGESIO JOSH JETER, p.g.a. ELISABET
